abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, and the institutional
            development impact is substantial, with both performances by
            the Bank, and Borrower, rated satisfactory. Among the
            lessons learned, an interesting point is raised: the gradual
            - though dramatic - changes the development agenda continues
            to experience, conduces also to changes in the composition
            of the Bank's preparation team, or others, not
            necessarily being documented, nor sufficiently explicit so
            as to allow a broader debate on other support options. This
            situation is reflected in this operation's disconnect
            between expectations and accountabilities actually
            negotiated, with those that appeared in the credit
            agreement. Currently, the use of the Logframe format as a
            tool for project summary to assure consistency, would have
            improved the project's rationale, regrettably not in
            existence at the time of project inception. The
            implementation readiness adopted by the project (even in
            light of risks associated with new institutional
            arrangements) - experienced through a phased approach in
            resources utilization, followed by a staged increase in
            municipal management and subproject investments - fostered
            ownership by municipalities, focused on reform, though, the
            subsequent adoption by the Bank of the adaptable lending
            instruments, proved less subject to classical preparation
            prior to implementation as a means of managing risks, than
            traditionally. Consequently, the adoption of the pilot
            project approach (requiring preparation on project criteria)
            could have explicitly planned the necessary benchmarks ex
            ante. This said, the Midterm Review conducted an ex-post
            review, from which lessons were incorporated in a follow-up operation.
